items.title: Leveraging tax credits and incentives for sustainability projects

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Randa Barsoum, Tax Partner at PwC US, highlights tax credits and incentives beyond the usual energy-focused programs that can support sustainability initiatives. She points to state and local abatements, location-based incentives, and R&D tax credits tied to innovation (such as reimagining packaging or processes), and emphasizes that a broader view of tax opportunities can unlock meaningful tax value from sustainability investments.
bullets: Energy incentives are well known but not the whole picture.
State and local abatements can support sustainability projects.
Location-based incentives offer additional site-specific value.
R&D tax credits can apply to innovation in processes and packaging.
Viewing sustainability investments broadly can unlock meaningful tax value.
takeaways: Donâ€™t rely only on federal energy creditsâ€”investigate state and local abatements that may apply to grid or data center projects.
Factor location-based incentives into site selection to improve project economics.
Document innovation in operational processes or infrastructure (e.g., cooling, efficiency improvements) to pursue R&D tax credits.
Frame sustainability investments to capture a wider set of incentives and enhance overall tax value.

items.title: Bringing In $251K A Year With 3 Jobs In The Bay Area

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Naseema McElroy, 44, is a labor and delivery nurse in Brentwood, California who started a personal finance brand, Financially Intentional, to document her journey after accumulating nearly $1 million in debt in 2015. By 2017 she had paid off her debt; the video is part of CNBC Make It's Millennial Money series.
